THE LEOPARDS ARCH

If you're visiting or driving by Logan Elementary School, you'll see an impressive addition to the Elmwood Avenue campus.

In February, artist Bob Doster worked with the Logan Leopards (the school's mascot is the leopard) to create a piece of art that depicts Logan's mission to rise above and reach new heights through unity. The Leopards Arch is comprised of the handprints of Logan students and staff. The handprints form an archway of two leopards leaping toward each other.

Logan students and staff extend their special thanks to their school community and Bob Doster’s Backstreet Studio, Ltd.

R1 MIDDLE SCHOOL ATHLETICS

Richland One is beginning middle school athletic conditioning and fall sports practices. Middle school volleyball conditioning starts today (August 17) and the normal volleyball practices will begin August 28. Students will need to have an updated physical dated April 1, 2020 or later. Middle school football and cheerleading will be able to begin conditioning on August 24. Their normal practices will begin on September 8.

All students will be screened as they arrive for practice. Screening will include a temperature check and COVID-19 questions.

Parents should contact their child's school if they have questions or need additional information.

The FCCLA's Master Adviser Award acknowledges innovative teachers who have successfully advised an affiliated chapter for a minimum of three years; continuously promote family and consumer sciences (FCS) education; and motivate and mentor students to reach their highest potential. South Carolina Appleseed Legal Justice Center is sharing a COVID-19 Update.
July 1 at 4:42 PM ·

Eligible South Carolina households will receive a food assistance boost in July through a new federal program called Pandemic EBT (“P-EBT”). P-EBT is available for school-aged children who receive free or reduced-price meals, when school is open. The average benefit will be $5.70 per day, per child, which for South Carolina students will total approximately $330. The P-EBT benefit will be provided as a one-time payment, meant to reimburse families for food assistance lost during March 16th-June 10th.

For more information on this new program, including eligibility and how to access the funds, please see the guide on our website: http://www.scjustice.org/pandemic-ebt-in-sc/

P-EBT will be administered by the SC Department of Social Services; thanks DSS for all of your hard work on this program!

Our high school graduation ceremonies were scheduled for June 1, 2 and 3. Richland One and other school districts that hold their graduations at the Colonial Life Arena were notified today (April 9) that no events will be held at that venue until August 1.

While we know now that we will have to have our graduation ceremonies at another location, it is still uncertain when restrictions on large gatherings will be lifted, so our graduation dates may change as well.

This emergency senior nutrition program is to help our most vulnerable, senior citizens during the COVID-19 crisis. Senior Resources will provide five free meals, at a first come, first serve basis. This drive thru service will be offered for meal pick-up from 10:30 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. Recipients will drive up, provide a state issued id, their name, address and phone number, and we will hand them 5 sealed trays of a dietary approved nutritious meal.

Congratulations to Cheryl Hinton Harris, a member of the Richland One Board of School Commissioners, who is the new president of the South Carolina Caucus of Black School Board Members. She was elected during the association’s annual meeting on December 6, 2019. Her installation ceremony was held January 9, 2020 (pictured).

Commissioner Harris has served on the Richland One Board of School Commissioners for seven years – two as the Board’s secretary and four as chairwoman. She is the longest-serving female chairwoman and African-American woman in district history. She has reached Level 6 of the South Carolina School Boards Association’s Boardmanship Institute, which is the highest level obtainable.

A 1990 graduate of Lower Richland High School, Commissioner Harris is a proud product of Richland One. She served as a district volunteer for more than 13 years prior to being elected to the Board of School Commissioners in 2012. She represents Election District 4 on the Board. #R1Strong
